<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Four coordination polymers constructed from 4,4′-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene and 3,5-bis(1-imidazoly)pyridine with Zn(II) in different solvents and investigated the influence of decreased temperature rates on the structure of the resultant complexes.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Four coordination polymers constructed from 4,4'-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene and 3,5-bis(1-imidazoly)pyridine with Zn(II) in different solvents and investigated the influence of decreased temperature rates on the structure of the resultant complexes.

</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Using the same reactants, synthesized two structurally different Coordination polymers.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">An excellent luminescent property of coordination polymers was prepared.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Four novel coordination polymers (CPs), namely, [ZnL(bimb)]·DMF (1), [ZnL(bimb)]·6(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (2), [ZnL(bimp)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (3) and [ZnL(bimp)]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (4), (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid, bimb<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene, bimp<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3,5-bis(1-imidazoly)pyridine), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions with different solvents and decreased temperature rates. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by infrared spectra (IR), elemental analyses, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits an infinite 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework with (6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays the 2D undulated sheets leading to form a 3D framework with π-π interactions among layers in ABAB fashion. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits an infinite 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) topology. <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> exhibited 2D layer with {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·8} topology structure. Photoluminescence properties of 1–4 in solid state at ambient temperature were studied, too.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Using the same reactants, synthesized two structurally different Coordination polymers.   ⋅ An excellent luminescent property of coordination polymers was prepared.   

Using the same reactants, synthesized two structurally different Coordination polymers.

An excellent luminescent property of coordination polymers was prepared.

Abstract

Four novel coordination polymers (CPs), namely, [ZnL(bimb)]⋅DMF (1), [ZnL(bimb)]⋅6(H2O)0.5 (2), [ZnL(bimp)0.5]⋅3H2O (3) and [ZnL(bimp)]⋅7H2O (4), (H2L=4,4'-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid, bimb=1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene, bimp=3,5-bis(1-imidazoly)pyridine), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions with different solvents and decreased temperature rates. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by infrared spectra (IR), elemental analyses, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). 1 exhibits an infinite 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework with (66) topology. 2 displays the 2D undulated sheets leading to form a 3D framework with π-π interactions among layers in ABAB fashion. 3 exhibits an infinite 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with (412⋅63) topology. 4 exhibited 2D layer with {42⋅63⋅8} topology structure. Photoluminescence properties of 1-4 in solid state at ambient temperature were studied, too.

<ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Coordination polymers (CPs), is a coordination compound with repeating coordination entities extending in 1, 2 or 3 dimensions, which allows for the unambiguous determination of crystal structures using X-ray diffraction technique and further, the proof-of-concept demonstration of structure-property correlation therein. In recent years, the rational design and synthesis of such materials is frequently area of research not only for their intriguing topological architectures, but also due to their potential applications as solid functional materials in the research area of catalysis, molecular storage, biomedicine, chemical sensors, optics, and so on . For example, K. Leus and his colleagues have been presented an overview on the state of the art of the use of CPs as a heterogeneous catalyst in liquid phase oxidation reactions . V. Stavila and his collaborators illustrated some of the many emerging opportunities for using CPs in electronic and optoelectronic devices, established the structure-property relationships to identify and rationalize the factors that impact device performance, as well as summarizing various approaches to designing active CPs, integration of CPs with device hardware .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers (CPs), is a coordination compound with repeating coordination entities extending in 1, 2 or 3 dimensions, which allows for the unambiguous determination of crystal structures using X-ray diffraction technique and further, the proof-of-concept demonstration of structure-property correlation therein. In recent years, the rational design and synthesis of such materials is frequently area of research not only for their intriguing topological architectures, but also due to their potential applications as solid functional materials in the research area of catalysis, molecular storage, biomedicine, chemical sensors, optics, and so on . For example, K. Leus and his colleagues have been presented an overview on the state of the art of the use of CPs as a heterogeneous catalyst in liquid phase oxidation reactions . V. Stavila and his collaborators illustrated some of the many emerging opportunities for using CPs in electronic and optoelectronic devices, established the structure-property relationships to identify and rationalize the factors that impact device performance, as well as summarizing various approaches to designing active CPs, integration of CPs with device hardware .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Inspired by the above-mentioned points, we developed a rational synthetic strategy for synthesizing two novel entangled CPs by employing the bis(imidazole) ligands reacted with 4,4′-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L), which has remarkable features. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L, affords a lot of bridging modes with two carboxylate groups, (i) would be partially or completely deprotonated by tuning the reaction pH value; (ii) has the property of flexibility and conformational freedom to allow itself to deal with the coordination environment and to void interpenetrating or entangled structures; (iii) could be finally adopted in the formation of CPs . Up to now, it is well known that large number of CPs have been successfully synthesized by introducing a rigid N-donor ligand 1,4-bis(1-imidazoly)benzene . The diverse structures of them are always dependent on many factors, such as the chemical structure of the ligands chosen , metal ions , metal-ligand ratio , pH , counteranion , temperature , the solvent system , the methods of crystallization , and the number of coordination sites  provided by organic ligands, to mention a few. For instance, S. B. Jonnalagadda and his group gave a review on compiling and describing varied eccentric traits of CPs, synthetic approaches, and mechanisms corresponding to applications in the comprehensible way, and provided lucid information and insights into the influence of experimental conditions on CPs structures .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the above-mentioned points, we developed a rational synthetic strategy for synthesizing two novel entangled CPs by employing the bis(imidazole) ligands reacted with 4,4'-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid (H2L), which has remarkable features. H2L, affords a lot of bridging modes with two carboxylate groups, (i) would be partially or completely deprotonated by tuning the reaction pH value; (ii) has the property of flexibility and conformational freedom to allow itself to deal with the coordination environment and to void interpenetrating or entangled structures; (iii) could be finally adopted in the formation of CPs . Up to now, it is well known that large number of CPs have been successfully synthesized by introducing a rigid N-donor ligand 1,4-bis(1-imidazoly)benzene . The diverse structures of them are always dependent on many factors, such as the chemical structure of the ligands chosen , metal ions , metal-ligand ratio , pH , counteranion , temperature , the solvent system , the methods of crystallization , and the number of coordination sites  provided by organic ligands, to mention a few. For instance, S. B. Jonnalagadda and his group gave a review on compiling and describing varied eccentric traits of CPs, synthetic approaches, and mechanisms corresponding to applications in the comprehensible way, and provided lucid information and insights into the influence of experimental conditions on CPs structures .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Using selected examples of constructing metal-organic architectures from recent literature, P. Kanoo et al. discussed the influences of changing temperature in fixed stoichiometric reactions, molecular orientation in the unit cell during the crystallization process was decided under a given temperature-controlled synthesis condition . C. Y. Niu et al. described the influence of analogue dipyridyl ligands and bridging anions on structural diversity, showed that the structural diversity of the titled CPs probably results from the changes of secondary ligands and bridging anions, exhibited that the two factors play important roles in the construction of various CPs . Taking into account the factors mentioned above, we focused only our attention on the reactions of different solvents with polycarboxylate ligands and investigated the influence of decreased temperature rates on the structure of the resultant complexes. In this paper we describe the syntheses, crystal structures and properties of the CPs, namely, [ZnL(bimb)]·DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [ZnL(bimb)]·6(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [ZnL(bimp)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and [ZnL(bimp)]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Using selected examples of constructing metal-organic architectures from recent literature, P. Kanoo et al. discussed the influences of changing temperature in fixed stoichiometric reactions, molecular orientation in the unit cell during the crystallization process was decided under a given temperature-controlled synthesis condition . C. Y. Niu et al. described the influence of analogue dipyridyl ligands and bridging anions on structural diversity, showed that the structural diversity of the titled CPs probably results from the changes of secondary ligands and bridging anions, exhibited that the two factors play important roles in the construction of various CPs . Taking into account the factors mentioned above, we focused only our attention on the reactions of different solvents with polycarboxylate ligands and investigated the influence of decreased temperature rates on the structure of the resultant complexes. In this paper we describe the syntheses, crystal structures and properties of the CPs, namely, [ZnL(bimb)]⋅DMF (1), [ZnL(bimb)]⋅6(H2O)0.5 (2), [ZnL(bimp)0.5]⋅3H2O (3), and [ZnL(bimp)]⋅7H2O (4).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and instrumentation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L was synthesized by 4,4′-dibromotriphenylamine and Copper(I) cyanide then hydrolyzing . The 1,4-bis(imidazole-1-yl) benzene(bimb) and 3,5-bis(1-imidazoly) pyridine(bimb) ligands were purchased from Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co., Ltd. (in Shandong Province of China), all chemicals were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240c elemental analyzer. TGA was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 30 to 650<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under nitrogen. The luminescent properties of these compounds were measured on a HITACHI F-7000 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Perkin–Elmer 580B IR spectrometer in the 400–4000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and instrumentation

The H2L was synthesized by 4,4'-dibromotriphenylamine and Copper(I) cyanide then hydrolyzing . The 1,4-bis(imidazole-1-yl) benzene(bimb) and 3,5-bis(1-imidazoly) pyridine(bimb) ligands were purchased from Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co., Ltd. (in Shandong Province of China), all chemicals were used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed with a Perkin-Elmer 240c elemental analyzer. TGA was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 30 to 650°C under nitrogen. The luminescent properties of these compounds were measured on a HITACHI F-7000 spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Rigaku D/M-2200T automated diffractometer. IR spectra were obtained from KBr pellets on a Perkin-Elmer 580B IR spectrometer in the 400-4000cm-1 region.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of [ZnL(bimb)]·DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0297<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L (0.0333<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), bimb (0.0296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), were added to N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). The final mixture was placed in a Teflon reactor (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and heated at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After gradually cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, large quantities of colorless block crystals were obtained and the crystals were filtered off, washed with ethyl alcohol absolute, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 59% based on bimb. Elemental analysis calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">35</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>Zn (%): C, 61.81; H, 4.44; N, 12.36. Found: C, 61.87; H, 4.48; N, 12.31. FT-IR (4000–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3133 (m), 1665 (s), 1593 (s), 1532 (s), 1489 (m), 1362 (s), 1313(s), 1279 (s), 1070 (s), 960 (m), 784 (s), 656(m).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [ZnL(bimb)]⋅DMF (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297g, 0.1mmol), H2L (0.0333g, 0.1mmol), bimb (0.0296g, 0.1mmol), were added to N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF 8mL) and H2O (2mL). The final mixture was placed in a Teflon reactor (20mL) and heated at 80°C for 3days. After gradually cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1, large quantities of colorless block crystals were obtained and the crystals were filtered off, washed with ethyl alcohol absolute, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 59% based on bimb. Elemental analysis calcd for C35H30N6O5Zn (%): C, 61.81; H, 4.44; N, 12.36. Found: C, 61.87; H, 4.48; N, 12.31. FT-IR (4000-600cm-1): 3133 (m), 1665 (s), 1593 (s), 1532 (s), 1489 (m), 1362 (s), 1313(s), 1279 (s), 1070 (s), 960 (m), 784 (s), 656(m).

<ce:section-title id="st060">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Single-crystal XRD data for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) at 165(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares techniques by using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX . No-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single-crystal XRD data for compounds 1-4 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) at 165(2)K. Absorption corrections were applied using the multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by the full-matrix least-squares techniques by using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX . No-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-4 are summarized in  .

<ce:section-title id="st065">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st070">Structure description of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The crystal structure determination reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of <ce:italic>Pbcn</ce:italic>. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimb ligand and one deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and one DMF molecule, which is omitted for clarity (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) cation is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligand and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligands take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>a). The bond lengths of Zn–O bond distance vary in the range of 1.964(3)–1.970(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Zn–N bond distance is 2.029(3)–2.030(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). The N ligand connect Zn atoms to form a 1D chain. Then the L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands join all infinite 1D chains into a 3D framework. If L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and bimb are considered as linkers, Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus the topology of the structure can be simplified as<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a 3D framework of (6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology (b). Because of the space nature of the single structure, four identical structure mutually interpenetrate each other into a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c). Interestingly, in the structure the Zn centers are connected by organic ligands to build two different double helixes. Each double helixex can be split into two mirror-symmetric helical chains which combine together by sharing the Zn centers and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Structure description of 1 

The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of Pbcn. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimb ligand and one deprotonated L2- ligand and one DMF molecule, which is omitted for clarity ( a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) cation is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two H2L ligand and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the H2L ligands take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode ( a). The bond lengths of Zn-O bond distance vary in the range of 1.964(3)-1.970(3)Å and the Zn-N bond distance is 2.029(3)-2.030(3)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). The N ligand connect Zn atoms to form a 1D chain. Then the L2- ligands join all infinite 1D chains into a 3D framework. If L2- and bimb are considered as linkers, Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus the topology of the structure can be simplified asa 3D framework of (66) topology (b). Because of the space nature of the single structure, four identical structure mutually interpenetrate each other into a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c). Interestingly, in the structure the Zn centers are connected by organic ligands to build two different double helixes. Each double helixex can be split into two mirror-symmetric helical chains which combine together by sharing the Zn centers and L2- anions (d).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st075">Structure description of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The crystal structure determination reveals that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mspace width="0.35em"></mml:mspace>

</mml:math>. Theasymmetric unit contains two Zn(II) cation, two bimb ligand, two deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and six half of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule, which is omitted for clarity (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) ions is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligands take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (a). The bond lengths of Zn–O bond distance vary in the range of 1.943(4)–1.969(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Zn–N bond distance is 1.994(4)–2.036(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). In the structure, neighboring Zn(II) atoms are connected by bimb ligands to generate 1D chains, the 1D chains are bridged by L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into 2D sheets by the diagonal direction. If bimb and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are considered as connecters, the Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus the topology of the structure can be simplified as a (4,4) net (c). The sheets are stacked in ABAB fashion and form a 3D framework (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 2 

The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 2 crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of   P    1   ¯    . Theasymmetric unit contains two Zn(II) cation, two bimb ligand, two deprotonated L2- ligand and six half of H2O molecule, which is omitted for clarity ( a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) ions is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two L2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the H2L ligands take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (a). The bond lengths of Zn-O bond distance vary in the range of 1.943(4)-1.969(4)Å and the Zn-N bond distance is 1.994(4)-2.036(4)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). In the structure, neighboring Zn(II) atoms are connected by bimb ligands to generate 1D chains, the 1D chains are bridged by L2- ligands into 2D sheets by the diagonal direction. If bimb and L2- are considered as connecters, the Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus the topology of the structure can be simplified as a (4,4) net (c). The sheets are stacked in ABAB fashion and form a 3D framework (d).

<ce:section-title id="st080">Structure description of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group <ce:italic>P2/n</ce:italic>. In the asymmetric unit, it contains an independent Zn(II) cation, an L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand, a half of a bimp ligand and three H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a). The coordination geometry for each Zn atom is a distorted octahedron with four O atoms from four different ligands forming the middle plane. One nitrogen atom and one Znatom are in the axial position of the distorted octahedron. In this compound, the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L ligand acts as<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a “V-shape” link and the carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode (c) to bridge two Zn centers to form paddlewheel [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] clusters, the distance of Zn–Zn is 2.9746(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Zn–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.0225(19)–2.1314(19)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Zn–N bond length is 2.022(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). Each L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand links two Secondary building units (SBUs) to form a 2D layered network (b). Within the layer, there exists one 1D helical chain {- ZnL<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>- ZnL<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>}, with a pitch of 19.811<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å based of the repeat unit three Zn(II) and two L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> motifs (e  and f). Then the bimp ligand links the layers to further generate an infinite 3D framework (c). The dinuclear Zn(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with the L ligand acting aslinkers. A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as the Schlafli symbol {4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}, as displayed in d. Because of the space nature of the single structure, two identical structures mutually interpenetrate each other into a 2-fold interpenetrated framework (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 3 

Compound 3 crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group P2/n. In the asymmetric unit, it contains an independent Zn(II) cation, an L2- ligand, a half of a bimp ligand and three H2O molecules ( a). The coordination geometry for each Zn atom is a distorted octahedron with four O atoms from four different ligands forming the middle plane. One nitrogen atom and one Znatom are in the axial position of the distorted octahedron. In this compound, the H2L ligand acts asa "V-shape" link and the carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode (c) to bridge two Zn centers to form paddlewheel [Zn2(CO2)4] clusters, the distance of Zn-Zn is 2.9746(6)Å. The Zn-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.0225(19)-2.1314(19)Å and the Zn-N bond length is 2.022(2)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). Each L2- ligand links two Secondary building units (SBUs) to form a 2D layered network (b). Within the layer, there exists one 1D helical chain {- ZnL2-- ZnL2-}, with a pitch of 19.811Å based of the repeat unit three Zn(II) and two L2- motifs (e  and f). Then the bimp ligand links the layers to further generate an infinite 3D framework (c). The dinuclear Zn(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with the L ligand acting aslinkers. A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as the Schlafli symbol {412⋅63}, as displayed in d. Because of the space nature of the single structure, two identical structures mutually interpenetrate each other into a 2-fold interpenetrated framework (d).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st085">Structure description of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The crystal structure determination reveals that compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic>. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimp ligand, one deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand and seven H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecule, which is omitted for clarity (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) ions is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimp ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (a). The bond lengths of Zn–O bond distance vary in the range of 1.933(3)–1.945(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond distance is 2.028(4)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure description of 4 

The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 4 crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group C2/c. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimp ligand, one deprotonated L2- ligand and seven H2O molecule, which is omitted for clarity ( a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) ions is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two L2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimp ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the L2- ligand take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (a). The bond lengths of Zn-O bond distance vary in the range of 1.933(3)-1.945(3)Å, and the Zn-N bond distance is 2.028(4)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range ().

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0080" view="all">In the structure, neighboring Zn(II) atoms are connected by bimp ligands to generate 1D chains, the 1D chains are bridged by L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands into 2D sheets by the diagonal direction. If bimp and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are considered as connecters, the Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus, the topology of the structure can be simplified as a (4,4) net the Schlafli symbol {4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·8} (b and c). The sheets are in ABAB stacked fashion and form a 3D framework (d).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the structure, neighboring Zn(II) atoms are connected by bimp ligands to generate 1D chains, the 1D chains are bridged by L2- ligands into 2D sheets by the diagonal direction. If bimp and L2- are considered as connecters, the Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus, the topology of the structure can be simplified as a (4,4) net the Schlafli symbol {42⋅63⋅8} (b and c). The sheets are in ABAB stacked fashion and form a 3D framework (d).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Within the layer, there exists one 1D helical chain {-Zn(bimp)- ZnL<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>-Zn(bimp)- ZnL<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>}, with a pitch of 21.461<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å based of the repeat unit of one bimp ligands three Zn(II) and one L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> motifs (g). Both of them exhibits the uniform hardness in one layer, the opposite hardness in the other layer (e and f).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Within the layer, there exists one 1D helical chain {-Zn(bimp)- ZnL2--Zn(bimp)- ZnL2-}, with a pitch of 21.461Å based of the repeat unit of one bimp ligands three Zn(II) and one L2- motifs (g). Both of them exhibits the uniform hardness in one layer, the opposite hardness in the other layer (e and f).

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st090">Thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">To characterize the thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, their thermal behaviors were investigated by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> under nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the weight loss in the range of 25–270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is attributed to the release of one free DMF molecules (obsd 9.68%, calcd 10.75%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 11.2%, calcd 11.9%). For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss in the range of 25–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is ascribed to the departure of six free water molecules (obsd 11.43%, calcd 8.52%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.5%, calcd 13.4%). For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the weight loss in the range of 25–350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules (obsd 9.78%, calcd 9.96%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 15.8%, calcd 15.1%). For <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the weight loss in the range of 25–330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules. The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.0%, calcd 8.2%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

To characterize the thermal stabilities of compounds 1-4, their thermal behaviors were investigated by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1-4 under nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C/min. For 1, the weight loss in the range of 25-270°C is attributed to the release of one free DMF molecules (obsd 9.68%, calcd 10.75%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 350°C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 11.2%, calcd 11.9%). For 2, the weight loss in the range of 25-250°C is ascribed to the departure of six free water molecules (obsd 11.43%, calcd 8.52%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 400°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.5%, calcd 13.4%). For 3, the weight loss in the range of 25-350°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules (obsd 9.78%, calcd 9.96%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 15.8%, calcd 15.1%). For 4, the weight loss in the range of 25-330°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules. The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.0%, calcd 8.2%).

elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence properties

Because of the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal coordination polymers , the Zn(II) ion that can usually have a low coordination number of four with a tetrahedral coordination geometry, the luminescent properties of the compounds 1-4, and H2L were investigated separately in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in ( ). The emission peaks at 427nm for H2L (λex =397nm). the emission peaks were at 452nm in compound 1 (λex =395nm), 455nm in compound 2 (λex =388nm), 445nm in compound 3 (λex =359nm), 446nm in compound 4 (λex =375nm). These emissions it can be assigned to the intraligand (π-π∗ or π∗-n) fluorescent emission within the molecular orbital manifolds of the imidazolyl of bimb and bimp moieties and phenyl rings of H2L moieties because almost similar emission are observed for the free H2L. Compound 1-4 exhibits mission characteristics similar to those of the H2L ligand but Compound 1 and Compound 2 shows an obvious red shift about 25 and 28nm as compared with that of the H2L ligand, Compound 3 andCompound 4 shows about 18 and 19nm. The phenomenon may be assigned to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). These compounds may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue-fluorescent materials, since they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st100">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In this study, four new coordination polymers with novel architectures have been synthesized successfully under hydrothermal conditions with different solvents and decreased temperature rates by using the flexible carboxylic acid and the rigid N-donor ligands as auxiliary ligands. Their structural differences indicates that the solvothermal conditions and the reaction temperature have remarkable influence on the resultant topologies. The results also show that the flexible carboxylic acid are good candidates for the construction of high dimensional CPs. The photoluminescent behaviors show that these complexes may be good candidates for optical materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, four new coordination polymers with novel architectures have been synthesized successfully under hydrothermal conditions with different solvents and decreased temperature rates by using the flexible carboxylic acid and the rigid N-donor ligands as auxiliary ligands. Their structural differences indicates that the solvothermal conditions and the reaction temperature have remarkable influence on the resultant topologies. The results also show that the flexible carboxylic acid are good candidates for the construction of high dimensional CPs. The photoluminescent behaviors show that these complexes may be good candidates for optical materials.

Synthesis of [ZnL(bimb)]⋅DMF (1)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297g, 0.1mmol), H2L (0.0333g, 0.1mmol), bimb (0.0296g, 0.1mmol), were added to N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF 8mL) and H2O (2mL). The final mixture was placed in a Teflon reactor (20mL) and heated at 80°C for 3days. After gradually cooling to room temperature at a rate of 10°Ch-1, large quantities of colorless block crystals were obtained and the crystals were filtered off, washed with ethyl alcohol absolute, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 59% based on bimb. Elemental analysis calcd for C35H30N6O5Zn (%): C, 61.81; H, 4.44; N, 12.36. Found: C, 61.87; H, 4.48; N, 12.31. FT-IR (4000-600cm-1): 3133 (m), 1665 (s), 1593 (s), 1532 (s), 1489 (m), 1362 (s), 1313(s), 1279 (s), 1070 (s), 960 (m), 784 (s), 656(m).

Synthesis of [ZnL(bimb)]⋅6(H2O)0.5 (2)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0297g, 0.1mmol), H2L (0.0333g, 0.1mmol), bimb (0.0296g, 0.1mmol), H2O (10mL) was placed in a Teflon reactor (20mL) and heated at 160°C for 3days. After gradually cooling to room temperature at a rate of 20°Ch-1, large quantities of colorlessblock crystals were obtained and the crystals were filtered off, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 61% based on bimb. Elemental analysis for C64H52N10O11Zn2 (%): C, 60.62; H, 4.13; N, 11.04. Found: C, 60.78; H, 3.96; N, 11.15. FT-IR (4000-600cm-1): 3133 (m), 1596 (s), 1665 (s), 1592 (s), 1365 (s), 1070 (m), 944 (m), 837 (s), 783 (m), 657 (m), 531 (m).

Synthesis of [ZnL(bimp)0.5]⋅3H2O (3)

Similarly, the procedure of preparing compound 3 is equal to the procedure of 1 by replacement of bimb by bimp (0.0211g, 0.1mmol). Large quantities of colorless block crystals were obtained and the crystals were filtered off, washed with ethyl alcohol absolute, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 64% based on bimb. Elemental analysis calcd for C51H35N7O13Zn2 (%): C, 56.47; H, 3.25; N, 9.04. Found: C, 56.17; H, 3.08; N, 9.38. FT-IR (4000-600cm-1): 3145 (m), 1678 (s), 1595 (s), 1536 (s), 1488 (m), 1390 (s), 1309 (s), 1247 (s), 1072 (s), 959 (m), 781 (s), 649 (m).

Synthesis of [ZnL(bimp)]⋅7H2O (4)

Similarly, the procedure of preparing compound 4 is equal to the procedure of 2 by replacement of bimb by bimp (0.0211g, 0.1mmol). Large quantities of colorlessblock crystals were obtained, filtered off, washed with ethanol, and dried under ambient conditions. Yield of the reaction was 52% based on bimb. Elemental analysis calcd for C31H36N6O11Zn (%): C, 50.72; H, 4.94; N, 11.45. Found: C, 50.46; H, 4.65; N, 11.89. FT-IR (4000-600cm-1): 3145 (m), 1630 (s),1595 (s), 1536 (s), 1390 (s), 1090 (m), 945 (m), 840 (m), 781 (m), 649 (m), 552(m)  .

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm). cln_elements.clean_text:
Highlights

   ⋅ Using the same reactants, synthesized two structurally different Coordination polymers.   ⋅ An excellent luminescent property of coordination polymers was prepared.   

Using the same reactants, synthesized two structurally different Coordination polymers.

An excellent luminescent property of coordination polymers was prepared.

Abstract

Four novel coordination polymers (CPs), namely, [ZnL(bimb)]⋅DMF (1), [ZnL(bimb)]⋅6(H2O)0.5 (2), [ZnL(bimp)0.5]⋅3H2O (3) and [ZnL(bimp)]⋅7H2O (4), (H2L=4,4'-(phenylazanediyl)dibenzoic acid, bimb=1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene, bimp=3,5-bis(1-imidazoly)pyridine), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions with different solvents and decreased temperature rates. Their structures have been determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by infrared spectra (IR), elemental analyses, and thermogravimetric analyses (TGA). 1 exhibits an infinite 4-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional (3D) framework with (66) topology. 2 displays the 2D undulated sheets leading to form a 3D framework with π-π interactions among layers in ABAB fashion. 3 exhibits an infinite 2-fold interpenetrated 3D framework with (412⋅63) topology. 4 exhibited 2D layer with {42⋅63⋅8} topology structure. Photoluminescence properties of 1-4 in solid state at ambient temperature were studied, too.

Results and discussion

Structure description of 1 

The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system of Pbcn. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimb ligand and one deprotonated L2- ligand and one DMF molecule, which is omitted for clarity ( a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) cation is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two H2L ligand and two nitrogen atoms from two bimb ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the H2L ligands take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode ( a). The bond lengths of Zn-O bond distance vary in the range of 1.964(3)-1.970(3)Å and the Zn-N bond distance is 2.029(3)-2.030(3)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). The N ligand connect Zn atoms to form a 1D chain. Then the L2- ligands join all infinite 1D chains into a 3D framework. If L2- and bimb are considered as linkers, Zn(II) centers can be clarified as four-connected nodes. Thus the topology of the structure can be simplified asa 3D framework of (66) topology (b). Because of the space nature of the single structure, four identical structure mutually interpenetrate each other into a 4-fold interpenetrated framework (c). Interestingly, in the structure the Zn centers are connected by organic ligands to build two different double helixes. Each double helixex can be split into two mirror-symmetric helical chains which combine together by sharing the Zn centers and L2- anions (d).

Structure description of 3 

Compound 3 crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group P2/n. In the asymmetric unit, it contains an independent Zn(II) cation, an L2- ligand, a half of a bimp ligand and three H2O molecules ( a). The coordination geometry for each Zn atom is a distorted octahedron with four O atoms from four different ligands forming the middle plane. One nitrogen atom and one Znatom are in the axial position of the distorted octahedron. In this compound, the H2L ligand acts asa "V-shape" link and the carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode (c) to bridge two Zn centers to form paddlewheel [Zn2(CO2)4] clusters, the distance of Zn-Zn is 2.9746(6)Å. The Zn-O bond lengths are in the range of 2.0225(19)-2.1314(19)Å and the Zn-N bond length is 2.022(2)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range (). Each L2- ligand links two Secondary building units (SBUs) to form a 2D layered network (b). Within the layer, there exists one 1D helical chain {- ZnL2-- ZnL2-}, with a pitch of 19.811Å based of the repeat unit three Zn(II) and two L2- motifs (e  and f). Then the bimp ligand links the layers to further generate an infinite 3D framework (c). The dinuclear Zn(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with the L ligand acting aslinkers. A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as the Schlafli symbol {412⋅63}, as displayed in d. Because of the space nature of the single structure, two identical structures mutually interpenetrate each other into a 2-fold interpenetrated framework (d).

Structure description of 4 

The crystal structure determination reveals that compound 4 crystallizes in themonoclinic crystal system in space group C2/c. Theasymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one bimp ligand, one deprotonated L2- ligand and seven H2O molecule, which is omitted for clarity ( a). In the asymmetric unit, the Zn(II) ions is coordinated by two carboxylic O atoms from two L2- ligands and two nitrogen atoms from two bimp ligands to form a distorted tetrahedron geometry. In an asymmetric unit, the two carboxylate groups of the L2- ligand take the same coordination modes. They all take a monodentate coordination mode (a). The bond lengths of Zn-O bond distance vary in the range of 1.933(3)-1.945(3)Å, and the Zn-N bond distance is 2.028(4)Å. All these distances and bond angles are within the normal range ().

Thermal analysis

To characterize the thermal stabilities of compounds 1-4, their thermal behaviors were investigated by thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) (). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1-4 under nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°C/min. For 1, the weight loss in the range of 25-270°C is attributed to the release of one free DMF molecules (obsd 9.68%, calcd 10.75%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 350°C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 11.2%, calcd 11.9%). For 2, the weight loss in the range of 25-250°C is ascribed to the departure of six free water molecules (obsd 11.43%, calcd 8.52%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 400°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.5%, calcd 13.4%). For 3, the weight loss in the range of 25-350°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules (obsd 9.78%, calcd 9.96%). The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 15.8%, calcd 15.1%). For 4, the weight loss in the range of 25-330°C is ascribed to the departure of three free water molecules. The destruction of the framework occurs at ca. 370°C, finally leading to the formation of the stoichiometric amount of ZnO as residue (obsd 11.0%, calcd 8.2%).

Photoluminescence properties

Because of the excellent luminescent properties of d10 metal coordination polymers , the Zn(II) ion that can usually have a low coordination number of four with a tetrahedral coordination geometry, the luminescent properties of the compounds 1-4, and H2L were investigated separately in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in ( ). The emission peaks at 427nm for H2L (λex =397nm). the emission peaks were at 452nm in compound 1 (λex =395nm), 455nm in compound 2 (λex =388nm), 445nm in compound 3 (λex =359nm), 446nm in compound 4 (λex =375nm). These emissions it can be assigned to the intraligand (π-π∗ or π∗-n) fluorescent emission within the molecular orbital manifolds of the imidazolyl of bimb and bimp moieties and phenyl rings of H2L moieties because almost similar emission are observed for the free H2L. Compound 1-4 exhibits mission characteristics similar to those of the H2L ligand but Compound 1 and Compound 2 shows an obvious red shift about 25 and 28nm as compared with that of the H2L ligand, Compound 3 andCompound 4 shows about 18 and 19nm. The phenomenon may be assigned to ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT). These compounds may be suitable as excellent candidates of blue-fluorescent materials, since they are highly thermally stable and insoluble in common solvents.
